Interview with Eli Dortort
August 3, 2005
Beginning Tape One, Side A

segments.question: This is a United States Holocaust Memorial Museum volunteer collection interview with Eli Dortort, conducted by Gail Schwartz on August 3", 2005 in Kensington, Maryland. This is tape number one, side A. What is your full name?
segments.answer: Right now? Eli Dortort.

segments.question: Is that the name that you were born with?
segments.answer: No. I used to have a different name, and my name was Klemfner. But I was in the Polish army, and I deserted. So then I changed my name.

segments.question: When were you born?
segments.answer: Hm?

segments.question: When were you born?
segments.answer: I was born 1920, August, au -- au -- August the first, 1920.

segments.question: Oh. So your birthday was two days ago?
segments.answer: What?

segments.question: Your birthday was two days ago?
segments.answer: No, my birthday was not two days ago, because I -- let me tell you. My birthday was not two days ago, but my birthday will be the twent -- the 29 -- the s -- the 30" of August. Interview with Eli Dortort ° August 3, 2005

segments.question: Okay. And where were you born?
segments.answer: I was born in Poland, Galicia. It was a terrible country, I wish they would never be existing, but then I wouldn’t be here.

segments.question: What was the name of your town?
segments.answer: Of the ta -- town? Zdachov, Zdachov. That was named after a Polish judge who was ju -- at the time, and they named it after him.

segments.question: And was it near a bigger town? W-Was it near a larger town?
segments.answer: No, it was a very small town. For -- was basically a -- a town where you call a little bit -- a little bit bigger, but let me give you what I want to say. The town was very small, prob about 6,000 people there are living, 6,000 people, and there was a big Jewish community there. I was the youngest from my family.

segments.question: Let’s talk about your family now. How long had your family been living 1n this town?
segments.answer: Approximately al -- over -- let me see. I have to remember --

segments.question: Were your parents born in this town?
segments.answer: No, no, no, but -- no, my father, not my mother was born in there.

segments.question: All right, what was your father’s name?
segments.answer: Abraham Klemfner.

segments.question: And what did he do? Interview with Eli Dortort ° August 3, 2005
segments.answer: He -- when he came to [indecipherable] basically he came from a very rich family, but they were afraid he will be assimilated and he’ll forget all the Jewish thing [indecipherable] they were interested my father will know. So -- and then happened, he was a cattle dealer.

segments.question: Wh-Where was he born, where did he grow up?
segments.answer: He was born -- the -- the mountains, Sopwat, they call it Sopwat. They were -- in the mountains that were from -- let me give you right away. He was born in the a- the country -- on the mountains in the country there, there were a very small Jewish community.

segments.question: And tell me about your mother, what was her name?
segments.answer: What?

segments.question: Your mother, what was her name?
segments.answer: Frieda --

segments.question: What was her name?
segments.answer: Frieda Dortort, originally her name was Frieda Dortort.

segments.question: And where was she born?
segments.answer: She was born in another town in Poland called Gliniany. Gliniany. People ask me where it was, I would not be able to tell you.

segments.question: And how did your parents meet each other?
segments.answer: What? Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Eli Dortort : August 3, 2005

segments.question: How did your parents meet each other?
segments.answer: They were European. I must know the whole question what you ask me.

segments.question: I was asking how your mother and your father came to know each other?
segments.answer: Oh. My pi -- my mother was a -- a little bit an old woman already at the time. She was 70 years old. No, seve -- 74, something like this, in the 70’s, and there was a Shadchen. You know what a shadchen is? In to a shadchen they meet and liked each other.

segments.question: Ah, through a mat -- through a matchmaker we call --
segments.answer: [sings] Matchmaker, matchmaker, make me a match.

segments.question: Right. Okay. Then how many children did they have, your mother and your father?
segments.answer: My father have -- my mother had first of all her own children. We were eight.

segments.question: And where were you, were the eldest or the youngest or in the middle?
segments.answer: I was a very little boy. I was the youngest of all of them.

segments.question: Uh-huh, uh-huh.
segments.answer: I was the youngest of all of them, and when I was born, I was very young. You know I was young. You know, I -- right now I look for words.

segments.question: Okay. Let’s talk about your childhood. What memories do you have of childhood? Were you -- was your family very religious? Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Eli Dortort ° August 3, 2005
segments.answer: First of all, I have a Jewish education. I went to chaider when I was three -- three years old, Jewish boys used to start learn Jewish things. And then I went to the public school.

segments.question: And when you were in public school, did you have non-Jewish friends?
segments.answer: No, that was a mixed. Was Polish and Ukrainian and then was Jewish.

segments.question: Mm-hm, mm-hm. How old were you when you went to public school?
segments.answer: Three -- no [indecipherable] I will tell you right away, six years old.

segments.question: And what -- what did you like to do? Did you have any hobbies, did you have any interests besides school?
segments.answer: You’re talking about -- about a very small town, forget about hobbies, I used to like to play. But I used to go a whole day to schools, because when we used to finish one school, then I used to go to the other school, which was called chaider or Talmud Torah, whatever it was called, I don’t remember exactly, but this was how it was called.

segments.question: And your family was a very religious family?
segments.answer: Extremely, extremely, I could not describe to you. Today, when I remind myself how they’re so fanatic, I could not tell you even. They were very religious, and I will tell you, when we used to have Passover, we used to have m-matzos, shmeary matzos -- you know what shmeary matzos are? And then they used to bake them every Pesach, is -- exodus from Egypt, to remember the exodus from Egypt. And Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Eli Dortort ° August 3, 2005 then they used to not eat all the shmeary matzos, my p-parents and my -- and one brother. And we were extremely, extremely religious.

segments.question: Uh-huh. What language did you speak at home?
segments.answer: Yiddish. Yiddish.

segments.question: And what were the names of your brothers and sisters?
segments.answer: My -- I have two kind of brothers. My father married the second time my mother, and th -- they ha -- he had four children, two boys and two girls. One bo -- the boys, they went away from us, they didn’t stay too long with us, and I remember them both. One girl, she was run away to -- to Vienna, I never met her. And one g-g-girl, she got married in -- in the small town there.

segments.question: And what about your mother’s children?
segments.answer: My mother’s children, only it was -- what I was with, my a -- my mother didn’t have any other children. My mother was very old maid. She was about is -- a -- 18 years old when she got married. Not 18 -- 18 years, yeah, I am right, 18 years old.

segments.question: And you were the only child she had?
segments.answer: And I’m the -- I was the baby.

segments.question: Were there -- did she have other children?
segments.answer: What?

segments.question: Did she have other children? Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Eli Dortort ' August 3, 2005
segments.answer: No, only the children what she have with ma -- the second husband, was my father.

segments.question: And what were those children’s names?
segments.answer: Which one you want to know first?

segments.question: The oldest.
segments.answer: The old -- which, my mother or my father?

segments.question: Your mother.
segments.answer: Mother. The oldest was name -- wait one -- I will give it to you. The oldest n -- was named Yitzhak. The second one was named Mordechai. The third one was named -- Mordechai, yes, I-I made a little bit confusion. You know, Mordechai and then was named yak -- not Yakob, was not from mine father.

segments.question: Okay, okay, we’ll get back to that later. Did you -- did you play with Polish children?
segments.answer: Very little, hardly any. We didn’t mix.

segments.question: Uh-huh, uh-huh.
segments.answer: Ver -- by us intermarriage would be a unbelievable thing. The whole time would have talked was one Jewish woman. She wa -- she was a lawyer, she was [indecipherable]. But that’s the only thing what I could remember.

segments.question: Did you like sports when you were a young child? Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Eli Dortort ° August 3, 2005
segments.answer: Yeah, I liked sports, but not sports like here. I used to like to play soccer, which this is football in Poland. I used to -- I used to play soccer. I used to be a good player. You know, you had to run a lot, and I used to be a good runner. I used to ye- | -- | -- what you call a [indecipherable] on the front and you catch everything. I forgot --

segments.question: Any other sports, or just soccer?
segments.answer: Just a -- we -- we didn’t have too much like here, I must tell you right away.

segments.question: Did you like to read books?
segments.answer: A little bit, yes, yes. I still like to read, even today, which I -- what I’m not the same person than I used to be. Even today I like to read very often, current event.

segments.question: Yes. Was your family a Zionist --
segments.answer: What?

segments.question: Was your family a Zionist family?
segments.answer: What?

segments.question: Zionist.
segments.answer: Zi -- yes, yes. We all believed in Israel. We all believed -- we didn’t -- they used to believe in the Messiah will come, then we will go to Israel. And then the Jewish state was born, they were all still alive. And I couldn’t tell you, and I remember it very well already because I was a big boy already. The joy was so big, indescribable. If I would describe -- was like Messiah came, really. The joy -- the Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Eli Dortort ” August 3, 2005 Jewish e -- had such a joy that si -- I -- hard to describe, hard to describe. They started to dance. Saturday night when the -- the -- the decision in the United Nation came to us, I mean, they started to dance. Saturday night [indecipherable] a-after the -- the --

segments.question: Havdalah.
segments.answer: Havda -- after Havdalah, yes, good, very good, thank you. After Havdalah, and they start Monday morning dancing. And whatever anybody had on the roads they put out -- it was already -- Jewish people were already killed on the roads.

segments.question: Yeah. We’ll get to that a little later. We’re still in your childhood. But that’s a wonderful description.
segments.answer: Okay, a -- I didn’t know what to start with.

segments.question: No -- yeah. Did you have a lot of relatives, like grandparents and aunts and uncles and cousins in your town?
segments.answer: I will be honest with you, my mother had brothers in America. [coughs] Excuse me. Y-You know, when I speak too much, start to come out something. On the a -- nothing [indecipherable]. One second I will come back ...

segments.question: How would you describe yourself? Were you a very independent child? How would -- when you were young --
segments.answer: Yeah?

segments.question: -- were you a -- a fa -- Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Eli Dortort " August 3, 2005
segments.answer: What age, approximately, do you mean?

segments.question: Oh, when you were 10 - 11 - 12, wha --
segments.answer: | --that’s -- I was at home, and I studied all Jewish, or going to the Polish school.

segments.question: Tell -- tell me about your Bar Mitzvah. Your Bar Mitzvah was at --
segments.answer: I will tell you, you will laugh. You know how much my Bar Mitzvah cost? Swear to God, about 15 cents. My mother made a cake. She didn’t go to the store to buy it, because was no such a store they selled cakes. But she went -- she baked a cake and my father bought one-tenth of a liter vodka. And they brought it to shul, and then they -- I ma -- I made a [indecipherable] and that’s all. But -- but I studied the tal -- not the Talmud, the Jewish [indecipherable] right away started then, before I came Bar Mitzvahed because you have a lot to know in the Jewish [indecipherable] law. And that’s -- I started ver -- one year almost. The best teachers they ever were there -- and we were very poor, they didn’t try to save money, anything on this. This was an event where they want to treat me.

segments.question: So did you -- did you read from -- chant from the Torah at your Bar Mitzvah service?
segments.answer: What?

segments.question: Did you chant from the Torah at your Bar Mitzvah service?
segments.answer: Yeah, sure, sure. They gave us ra -- possible my Bar Mitzvah was [indecipherable] middle of the day I [indecipherable] to the Jewish calendar. And Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Eli Dortort " August 3, 2005 no, I didn't do much more than this, because I -- I was studying the Jewish law since childhood. Since childhood, yes, so then I started a little bit more because was more to be learned, and that’s all.

segments.question: And di-did you get any gifts for your Bar Mitzvah?
segments.answer: Nobody -- who gaves gifts? People are poor country. Nobody would give biz -- somebody a gift when he’s going into be a Bar Mitzvah. Here they make a big deal from it, but not there, man.

segments.question: Tell me what kind of work your father did.
segments.answer: My father, first of all, he came from a village 1-in the Carpathian mountains [indecipherable] his father -- they moved him away -- they used to live in Lemberg. And Lemberg become a very assimilated state, so my grandfather -- I did not know him -- I guess I know him for a few months -- I -- I was a little boy when he passed away.

segments.question: What kind of work did your father do?
segments.answer: What?

segments.question: What kind of work did your father do?
segments.answer: My father became a butcher. He didn’t wanted to become a butcher, but that’s the va -- only thing he could do, because he -- he selled cattles. And the cattle business was much bad, at one time they broke a leg. And when they broke a leg my father took a goy, you know what a goy is? The -- the goy was selling the meat. Interview with Eli Dortort " August 3, 2005 And he made a lot of money. So he say t -- able -- be able to do this all my life, and I will make a better living. And that’s all what w-was to it. And he became a butcher.

segments.question: Did your mother work or did she stay at home the whole time?
segments.answer: My mother worked when -- before -- she was a girl. She was 24 years old when she got married. Oh, an old maid. Sh-Sh-She was 24 years old. She used to know how to make certain things which nobody -- on machines, and machine she -- you save a machine -- she used to make socks, for the ever, whatever could come to her hand.

segments.question: So you’re now 13 years old, and now -- then you go into high school? You got --
segments.answer: What?

segments.question: You go into high school?
segments.answer: Who? High school, forget it. In Poland they didn’t have high school. We couldn’t afford to go to co -- in the Jewish school my parents didn’t save any money. I finished the high school, and that’s all it was to it.

segments.question: And then you started working?
segments.answer: What to do there? Was not what to do in a small town like mine.

segments.question: So what did you do?
segments.answer: Sometimes you know, I -- I’Il remember when they used to bake matzos, I used to go make th-the matzos because they took only Jewish children. And that’s very Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Eli Dortort " August 3, 2005 little bi -- but my brothers became butchers too, and they used to go to the villages and buy something and sell it, you know how it wa -- but it’s not a big deal.

segments.question: So when you were fi -- 14 - 15 - 16 and 17, what were you doing?
segments.answer: Was hardly anything to do. A small town you didn’t have -- sometimes they used to bring in certain things for you have to clean it out or whatever. So I used to go do it, but not always was this a-ability to do.

segments.question: All right. Did --
segments.answer: Do I give you a clear a-answer?

segments.question: Yes, it’s fine. It’s fine. So now, when were you first aware of a man named Hitler?
segments.answer: I what?

segments.question: When were you first aware --
segments.answer: Of Hitler?

segments.question: Of -- of Hitler.
segments.answer: Oh, I -- we knew it already when he came to power. He came to power -- we knew everything. These things -- we used to have radios, we used to have papers, that’s all. But we knew he’s not a good man. We knew right away -- none of the p - you know, when -- none of the Polacks, they were good people. I will tell you, they should have dropped dead before I knew them. They were terrible anti- Interview with Eli Dortort " August 3, 2005 Semites. And all the goyim, all the Gentiles, they help, I think, against the Jews, I apologize.

segments.question: So now, what is your memory, your first memory of the war when it began?
segments.answer: That was when the war broke out. The war break out in the first of the month, a -

segments.question: Fir -- September 1“, 1939.
segments.answer: That’s exactly when the war broke out.

segments.question: And so you are 19 years old.
segments.answer: I was 19 years old, yeah, correct.

segments.question: What -- can you describe that time, please?
segments.answer: First of all, we didn’t know what would come in, but then Hitler made that pact with the Germans and -- Russia make a pact, and we were glad the Russian coming in because they were not such murderers. This took approximately a few months, a year -- I would give you exactly the -- and then in June the next year, was on June something, th -- they came in, they invaded Poland.

segments.question: And -- and what are your memories of that time? Can you describe what your town was like then?
segments.answer: Which part you mean?

segments.question: When the Russians came into your town, what was it like? How did your life change? Interview with Eli Dortort : August 3, 2005
segments.answer: Right, first of all they not were so anti-Semites. They were more sympathetic Jewish people who c -- who had some intellectual, or ca-capability, they used to go to [indecipherable] offices, and so on. It was a different attitude altogether.

segments.question: What were you doing at the time that the Russians came in?
segments.answer: I was working in an office. I was a [indecipherable] for a [indecipherable] laboratories. I used to check [indecipherable] laboratories. This -- they first of all gave us a few months an exercise to it, or training. That what I used to do. Then came the Holocaust.

segments.question: Well, all right, the Russians came in and you were working in an office?
segments.answer: Yes, yes, yes.

segments.question: And then what was the next change? You were still living at home?
segments.answer: What?

segments.question: You were still living at home when you were 19?
segments.answer: I lived -- lived in home about a few months longer than two ye -- no, they -- in June, they came in in June, I remember right now. You know, sometimes my memory is not too good.

segments.question: And then what’s your next -- what is the next memory that you have? When the Germans came?
segments.answer: The German came in. I escaped the last minute, the last, I escape. They came in to us in a sa -- ina Saturday, June the ninth or the 10", I don’t remember exactly Interview with Eli Dortort .° August 3, 2005 the date they came in. If I would be there another hour, two hours or even a whole day, I wouldn’t be alive.

segments.question: How did you know to escape?
segments.answer: Here I will tell you. They was bi -- building a-air -- air drains -- air -- ai-airports, and I was working with them, and then they gave me a ride and took me to Kiev.

segments.question: Wh-Who did this?
segments.answer: The -- the people who used to work there, they were no Hitlers. They -- there are some people who I used to work with them, they were very pleasant to me, and I didn’t have any [indecipherable] and they took me o-on the car, that’s the [indecipherable]. Another Jewish boy came with the same car what I went, but otherwise they didn’t have too much place to take in.

segments.question: Yeah. Did you know you were going to be leaving?
segments.answer: What?

segments.question: Did you know that you were going to be leaving so soon?
segments.answer: I-I -- I -- fact, I didn’t know when I would see any more my parents and this was the last day I saw my parents.

segments.question: Were you able to say goodbye to them? Did you n -- did they know you were leaving?
segments.answer: What?

segments.question: Did your parents know you were leaving? Interview with Eli Dortort " August 3, 2005
segments.answer: My parents knew [indecipherable] I remember my brother have a few dollars in his pocket, he took out all the money and gave it to me because he knew I’m going away. He never would have had the feeling will be not a good trip.

segments.question: So you went to Kiev?
segments.answer: I-I -- the first stop I went to Kiev.

segments.question: And that was what, June 1941?
segments.answer: 1941 in June.

segments.question: Ah.
segments.answer: I don’t remember exactly what day in June it was, the first of June.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Do you have it right?

segments.question: This is a continuation of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum volunteer collection interview with Eli Dortort. This is tape number one, side B. And we were talking about how in ju -- in June 1941 --
-- you went -- the Russians took you to Kiev. How long did you stay there? Interview with Eli Dortort . August 3, 2005
segments.answer: In Kiev? In Kiev I stayed only two, three days, but then we went more deep because the German came already closer, so I knew there is not for me to wait, because we know we don’t want to see the Germans.

segments.question: And so where did you go?
segments.answer: I went a little bit forward, and let me see, where was the first --

segments.question: But what did -- did you work? What did you do after you left Kiev?
segments.answer: Yeah, I used to work in a laboratory, the same thing, because there was a Jewish manager and he gave me a break, and he took me in. And he gave me a few months, but then also we run away because this didn’t last too long.

segments.question: Who else were you wirth -- with, were you with somebody from your town?
segments.answer: What?

segments.question: Were you with another young man from your town?
segments.answer: I -- no, I didn’t have nobody from my town. No, I didn’t have nobody from mine town there. I have a guy which he came with me, he came til -- a -- a short time because the -- the Russian took us on a bus, me and him, and th -- you know, and they didn’t have too much more places us to take.

segments.question: So where did you after Kiev?
segments.answer: Ah, after Kiev I went Starobelsk. That was a little bit more -- were some Jewish people a little bit. But all along there was Jewish people, we feeled more Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Eli Dortort " August 3, 2005 comfortable. They have that because Russia has a big [indecipherable] of Jewish people, I don’t have to tell you, you know just as good as I do know.

segments.question: And do you -- and -- and what kind of work did you do there?
segments.answer: Paper mec -- I was not too long there. I also went into the Polish army. I volunteered. But we had a feeling we will turn out somewhere a little bit more comfortable, to be able to survive. Survival was the first in our mind, because I never -- God forbid Hitler comes, forget it. And the German advanced very fast, very fast, until they came to -- now, let me see where they came first -- until they came to Leningrad.

segments.question: So where did you join -- you said you joined the Polish army? And where did you do --
segments.answer: The Polish army I was only a very short time, til we came to Israel. When I came to Israel I had there families and I knew I will not go back with them. And we looked up -- for one day it was, before the high holidays -- during the high holidays, Jewish high holidays and somebody cames over to me, Eli, would you like to leave them? I say, for sure, what kind of a question is it? And I, at the time deserted the Polish army.

segments.question: So how long were you in the Polish army”?
segments.answer: A few months. Let me see how many months I was. It’s a little bit hard for me to remember. Very short time. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Eli Dortort August 3, 2005

segments.question: A-And then you left the polis -- P-Polish army --
segments.answer: I deserted.

segments.question: Uh-huh. How did you do that?
segments.answer: Somebody came over to me, Eli, would you like to live in Israel? I said, sure I would love to. This was Rosh Hashanah. You know what Rosh Hashanah is? That was Rosh Hashanah. And then they rented for us a bus, and they took us a little bit far -- further away, so nobody will be able to know where we are, and that’s all.

segments.question: So after you -- after you deserted the Polish army, you went directly to Palestine?
segments.answer: I was already in Palestine, only I transferred to the Jewish army a few months later because they didn’t want me to go around in the street and somebody will g -- recognize me.

segments.question: This is in Palestine?
segments.answer: This is -- was in Israel. We never called this land Palestine.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: We never in our life called it Palestine.

segments.question: Okay. So when you were in the Polish army, you were in Russia?
segments.answer: I went to the Polish army when I was in pola -- in Poland, the Polish army. They organized the Polish army. Do you know who p-paid for it? The American and the Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Eli Dortort August 3, 2005 British. They knew they could not discriminate because we were pol -- Polish citizens, and that’s how I got to Israel.

segments.question: What year did you get to Israel?
segments.answer: Maybe I -- a few months later, when I ran away.

segments.question: What year was that?
segments.answer: That was already ’72 - ’73.

segments.question: You mean 1942 - 1943?
segments.answer: Nine -- 1942 I was still in Poland.

segments.question: And then you went to Russia.
segments.answer: Then I went to Russia. We stayed there in the cold. I used to go to the forest, bringing wood [indecipherable] you know, I, by myself, used to go and bring water from the -- from our [indecipherable] so they could -- and they gave us soup. And they gave us so much soups I -- I was sick for a few days. Yes, yes, this is the truth.

segments.question: And so you were in the Polish army when you were in Russia, also?
segments.answer: Yeah, I was alre -- with the Polish army I went to Israel. Otherwise I wouldn’t be able to come to Israel.

segments.question: Oh, you went as a member of the --
segments.answer: Of the Polish army that transferred into Israel. Contact reference@ushmm.org for further information about tis collection Interview with Eli Dortort “ August 3, 2005

segments.question: Oh, I see. And so you -- you got to Israel, and where did you settle in Israel?
segments.answer: What?

segments.question: Where did you settle in 1 -- where did you live in Israel?
segments.answer: In Israel I lived in the -- in -- [indecipherable] in the Jordan riv -- by the Jordan river. I used to go bathing there almost every day. There was a little river.

segments.question: And -- and what -- did you work right away? What did you do?
segments.answer: I-I worked in the kibbutz.

segments.question: What -- what was the name of your kibbutz?
segments.answer: The kibbutz was named, let me see, I was -- I have so many names. The kibbutz name was --

segments.question: And what was your wife’s name?
segments.answer: Ruth.

segments.question: And tell me more about why you changed your name.
segments.answer: What?

segments.question: Tell me why -- again, why you changed your name to Dortort. Interview with Eli Dortort * August 3, 2005
segments.answer: Because I deserted the Polish army, and I didn’t want them they find me, and then they still have the English army, so I didn’t want to have this name, because I was a deserter at this time. Not only me, the greatest part of the Jews, see, people who were in the Polish army, they deserved it, too. I’m positive you know something about it. A bunch of haters. Could you imagine I was sleeping with them in one -- in one t -- tent, and all the time they were reading how many Jews they killed. Is this a civilized ki -- people? Even today they tell you about hating Jews, and they’re not afraid. In this United States I have the last couple of weeks such experience with American about hating. Hating open, open, not hi -- hi -- they don’t hide it.

segments.question: Wha-What was that experience?
segments.answer: What is the exper -- this is the experience. They hate you. They hate you because Jews. They don’t do it for any other -- do you know, one guy, he came over to me, and he said -- one guy to me he came over and he said, tha-that I -- I could not remember everything, that is my problem right now. If my problem would be what I could remember a little bit more, I could tell you a book. Because I was one time telling this story, and he said, you know, with your vocabulary and your what - with your stories, you should write a book. I loved it all.

segments.question: Oh. Interview with Eli Dortort “° August 3, 2005
segments.answer: I loved it. You see, I make an effort to tell you whatever I told you, but I don’t remember everything. My memory is not too good any more. But --

So that they used to wait for me to come and -- all the time for dinner, and I would tell them again the stories, but it’s all gone with the wind.

segments.question: Well, your daughter knows it, so it’s not gone.
segments.answer: What?

segments.question: Your daughter knows your stories, so it’s not gone.
segments.answer: I told her a lot of stories, yeah. I told her the truth. And everything what I say, I swear, every word is true what I say. I never told a lie. I’m not a bra -- a -- what you call it, a bre-breaking about it. Bra --

segments.question: Bragging.
segments.answer: Bragging about it. I never -- I never were a bragger. Even when I was something- my father was the same way. That’s -- I inherited from my father.
